questions.text: A 65-year-old male is in cardiac arrest due to refractory ventricular fibrillation after three unsuccessful defibrillation attempts. The resuscitation team decides to use double external defibrillation. What is the correct placement for the first defibrillator, and how should the second be positioned?

options.label: A
options.text: A) Left sternal border and left axilla; close to the first.

options.label: B
options.text: B) Right sternal border and cardiac apex; antero-posterior position.

options.label: C
options.text: C) Both pads on the same side; on the abdomen for the second.

options.label: D
options.text: D) Anteriorly on the chest; also anterior for the second with no specific placement.

questions.correct_answer: B. B) Right sternal border and cardiac apex; antero-posterior position.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male mountaineer plans a rapid ascent to an altitude of 4500 meters for a climbing expedition. He has a history of experiencing symptoms like fatigue, non-productive cough, and difficulty breathing during previous high-altitude trips. Based on the scenario, which of the following strategies should the mountaineer implement to effectively prevent symptoms, and what is the main treatment he should consider if symptoms develop?

options.label: A
options.text: Maintain an average altitude gain exceeding 300 m per day, and begin immediate treatment with acetazolamide.

options.label: B
options.text: Ascend rapidly without acclimatization, and use supplemental oxygen if symptoms develop.

options.label: C
options.text: Ascend slowly with a maximum altitude gain of 300 m per day, and prioritize descent of 1000 meters if symptoms occur.

options.label: D
options.text: Use alcohol to relax during the ascent, and rely solely on portable hyperbaric chambers if symptoms arise.

questions.correct_answer: C. Ascend slowly with a maximum altitude gain of 300 m per day, and prioritize descent of 1000 meters if symptoms occur.
questions.explanation:
High altitude pulmonary edema

Prevention
  • Slow ascent is the most effective method of prevention, even for susceptible individuals.
  • Graded ascent and adequate time for acclimatization.
  • Low sleeping altitudes.
  • Avoidance of alcohol and sleeping pills.
  • Avoidance of vigorous exercise, especially during the first days at altitude.
  • Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, can prevent HAPE in individuals with a history of the condition. The recommended dosage is 60 mg daily of a slow-release formulation, starting during ascent and continuing until the third or fourth day after arrival at the final altitude or after descending below 3000 m.
  • Preliminary data suggest glucocorticoids may prevent HAPE when taken one day prior to ascent and continued during ascent at high altitude.
  • Susceptible individuals should maintain an average altitude gain not exceeding 300 m per day above 2500 m.
  • If progressive acclimatization is not possible, prophylaxis with nifedipine or tadalafil is recommended for long stays at high altitude, and dexamethasone for short stays of less than 5 days.

Treatment
  • The mainstay of treatment is to descend 1000 meters or until symptoms resolve.
  • Minimize exertion during descent to reduce hypoxemia and worsening condition.
  • Oxygen therapy may help alleviate symptoms if descent is delayed or difficult.
  • Main treatment remains descent, regardless of oxygen availability.
  • Supplemental oxygen via high-flow nasal cannula and facemask should be titrated to SpO2 greater than 90%.
  • Portable hyperbaric chambers can be used if descent is not possible but require constant care.
  • Hyperbaric chambers may be challenging for individuals with nausea, vomiting, claustrophobia, or altered mental status from AMS/HACE.
  • There is a risk of symptom recurrence after exiting the hyperbaric chamber.
  • Nifedipine can improve symptoms as an adjunct therapy by reducing pulmonary vasoconstriction.
  • Nifedipine should not be the sole therapy if descent or oxygen is an option.
  • Phosphodiesterase inhibitors may help decrease pulmonary artery and capillary pressure through vasodilation if nifedipine is unavailable.
  • There is no clinically proven role for acetazolamide, β-agonists, or diuretics in the treatment of HAPE.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male skier is found unresponsive in the snow with a core body temperature of 27°C (81°F). He exhibits severe hypothermia and requires immediate medical attention. Which of the following is NOT a treatment approach for managing his hypothermia?

options.label: A
options.text: A) Administer warm intravenous fluids at 40-42°C.

options.label: B
options.text: B) Utilize ECMO (extracorporeal membrane oxygenation) to provide rewarming and circulatory support.

options.label: C
options.text: C) Use passive external rewarming by layering him with wet clothing.

options.label: D
options.text: D) Perform active internal rewarming using warm saline lavage of body cavities.

questions.correct_answer: C. C) Use passive external rewarming by layering him with wet clothing.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male fisherman is rescued after being exposed to cold water for several hours. Upon examination, his core body temperature is 29°C (84°F). He shows signs of lethargy, dilated pupils, and a slow heart rate. Which of the following statements about his condition is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Mild hypothermia typically presents with symptoms like shivering and increased muscle tone.

options.label: B
options.text: In moderate hypothermia shivering generally stops as the body temperature approaches 30°C.

options.label: C
options.text: Severe hypothermia can lead to unresponsiveness and increased risk of cardiac dysrhythmias.

options.label: D
options.text: Osborn waves are typically absent in hypothermic patients with temperatures below 28°C.

questions.correct_answer: D. Osborn waves are typically absent in hypothermic patients with temperatures below 28°C.
questions.explanation:
Hypothermia

Definition

Hypothermia is defined as a drop in core body temperature below 35°C, resulting in the failure to maintain homeostasis and affecting all organ systems.

Types
  • Primary Hypothermia: Caused by environmental cold exposure, such as cold air or water. Common in cold geographic areas but can also occur in mild climates.
  • Secondary Hypothermia: Results from conditions that impair heat production or increase heat loss (e.g., trauma, burns, drug overdoses, endocrine disorders, CNS injury, or drug effects).

Clinical Features

Mild Hypothermia (32-35°C / 90-95°F)

(Option A)

  • Symptoms: Hunger, nausea, fatigue, shivering, pale/dry skin, increased muscle tone, blood pressure, heart rate, and respiration.
  • Neurologic symptoms: Cognitive decline, memory impairment, ataxia, dysarthria.
  • Shivering may stop if energy stores are depleted (e.g., malnutrition).
  • Cold-induced diuresis due to peripheral vasoconstriction.

Moderate Hypothermia (28-32°C / 82-90°F)

(Option B)
  • Cognitive decline, lethargy, CNS depression (hyporeflexia, dilated pupils).
  • Shivering stops at 30-32°C.
  • Paradoxical undressing may occur.
  • Increased risk of atrial fibrillation, hypotension, bradycardia, bradypnea.

Severe Hypothermia (<28°C / <82°F)

(Option C)
  • Unresponsiveness, further decline in cerebral blood flow, hypotension, bradycardia, and cardiac output.
  • Risk of atrial, junctional dysrhythmias.
  • Pulmonary congestion, oliguria, and areflexia.
  • Potential for cardiorespiratory failure and death.

ECG Findings
  • Atrial Fibrillation: Most common arrhythmia in hypothermic patients.
  • Bradycardia: Seen in moderate to severe hypothermia, increasing the risk of ventricular arrhythmias.
  • QT Interval Prolongation: Due to slowed impulse conduction through potassium channels.
  • Osborn (J) Waves: Elevated J point, visible on ECG in the precordial leads, with wave height proportional to the degree of hypothermia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male hiker ascends rapidly from sea level to an altitude of 4500 meters over 24 hours. Two days after his arrival, he begins to experience increasing fatigue, a non-productive cough, and difficulty breathing during physical activity. His oxygen saturation is 60% on examination, and he exhibits tachypnea and cyanosis. Based on the scenario, which factors do not contribute to the patient's clinical features?

options.label: A
options.text: Low hypoxic ventilatory response (HVR)

options.label: B
options.text: Use of sleep medications during ascent

options.label: C
options.text: Recent heavy physical exertion prior to ascent

options.label: D
options.text: Extended acclimatization period before ascent

questions.correct_answer: D. Extended acclimatization period before ascent
questions.explanation:
High altitude pulmonary edema

About
  • HAPE is a severe, high-altitude illness, potentially fatal.
  • It is noncardiogenic pulmonary edema caused by hypoxia.
  • It occurs above 2500 meters, and can start as low as 2000 meters.
  • Risk factors: low hypoxic ventilatory response (HVR), rapid ascent, male sex, sleep medications, high salt intake, cold temperatures, and heavy exertion.
  • Pre-existing conditions (e.g., pulmonary hypertension) increase risk.
  • Faster ascent correlates with higher incidence.

Pathophysiology
  • HAPE results from the pulmonary vasculature's response to hypoxia.
  • Hypoxic ventilatory response (HVR) varies among individuals and has a genetic component.
  • High altitude adaptations include changes in resting ventilation, HVR, oxygen saturation, and hemoglobin concentration.
  • Rapid ascent to altitude causes immediate increases in minute ventilation and respiratory alkalosis.
  • Shifts in the oxygen-dissociation curve occur, initially increasing oxygen affinity, followed by a decrease as 2,3-DPG levels rise.
  • Blunted HVR (due to genetic factors or sedatives) leads to exaggerated hypoxemic pulmonary vasoconstriction (HPV).
  • HPV increases perfusion to affected alveoli, raising capillary pressures and permeability, leading to non-uniform pulmonary edema.
  • This edema further impedes oxygen transport and exacerbates pulmonary hypertension.

Clinical features
  • HAPE typically manifests 2 to 5 days after arriving at high altitude.
  • Initial symptoms include non-productive cough, decreased exercise tolerance, chest pain, and exertional dyspnea.
  • Progression can lead to dyspnea at rest, productive cough with pink frothy sputum, rales, and cyanosis.
  • Patients may exhibit tachypnea and tachycardia.
  • SpO2 levels are often significantly lower than expected for altitude, with values typically ranging from 40% to 70%.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, 36 weeks pregnant, is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at home. Upon arrival, she is unresponsive and in cardiac arrest. CPR is initiated immediately. The team begins advanced cardiac life support for pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to optimize maternal and fetal outcomes?

options.label: A
options.text: Delay chest compressions to position the patient for cesarean section.

options.label: B
options.text: Place the patient in a left lateral decubitus position and perform left uterine displacement.

options.label: C
options.text: Administer 2 mg epinephrine IV every 5 minutes.

options.label: D
options.text: Delay defibrillation to avoid harm to the fetus.

questions.correct_answer: B. Place the patient in a left lateral decubitus position and perform left uterine displacement.
questions.explanation:
Mnemonic

Causes of maternal cardiac arrest

A

Anesthetic Complications (Aspiration, High neuraxial block, Respiratory depression)

Accidents/ Trauma

B

Bleeding (Uterine atony, Placenta accreta, Abruption, Uterine rupture)

C

Cardiovascular Causes (MI, Cardiomyopathy, Valve disease, Congenital heart disease)

D

Drug-Related Issues (Oxytocin, Opioids, Illicit drugs, Anaphylaxis)

E

Embolic Causes (Amniotic fluid, Pulmonary, Venous air embolism)

F

Fever (Sepsis, Infection)

G

General Issues - H’s and T’s (causes of cardiac arrest)

H

Hypertension (Preeclampsia, Eclampsia, HELLP syndrome)

questions.text: A 62-year-old man was found unconscious at home and resuscitated after a cardiac arrest. He achieved Return of Spontaneous Circulation (ROSC) and was admitted to the ICU. By Day 3 (49-72 hours post-ROSC), the patient has been rewarmed, and sedation is being weaned off. Which of the following is an appropriate neuro-prognostic assessment to perform at this stage if the clinical condition allows it?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform a routine EEG to assess for seizure activity

options.label: B
options.text: Perform somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP)

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate Targeted Temperature Management (TTM)

options.label: D
options.text: Perform a neurological exam with a focus on pupillary and motor responses

questions.text: A 55-year-old man experiences a sudden cardiac arrest while jogging in a park. A bystander witnesses the collapse. According to the Adult OHCA Chain of Survival, what is the correct sequence of actions performed by the emergency responders in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Early recognition and Prevention → Activation of Emergency Response → Defibrillation → High-Quality CPR → Recovery→ Post-Cardiac Arrest Care

options.label: B
options.text: Activation of Emergency Response → High-Quality CPR → Defibrillation → Advanced Resuscitation → Post-Cardiac Arrest Care → Recovery

options.label: C
options.text: High-Quality CPR → Activation of Emergency Response → Advanced Resuscitation → Defibrillation → Post-Cardiac Arrest Care → Recovery

options.label: D
options.text: High-Quality CPR → Activation of Emergency Response → Defibrillation → Advanced Resuscitation → Post-Cardiac Arrest Care → Recovery

questions.correct_answer: B. Activation of Emergency Response → High-Quality CPR → Defibrillation → Advanced Resuscitation → Post-Cardiac Arrest Care → Recovery

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is found unresponsive at home. The parents initiate CPR, and the child is transported to the emergency department. Upon arrival, the medical team begins CPR and attaches a monitor/defibrillator. The rhythm check shows asystole. What is the next step in managing this child according to the Pediatric Cardiac Arrest Algorithm?

options.label: A
options.text: Deliver a shock immediately

options.label: B
options.text: Administer Amiodarone IV/IO

options.label: C
options.text: Administer Epinephrine and continue CPR

options.label: D
options.text: Administer Lidocaine IV/IO

questions.correct_answer: C. Administer Epinephrine and continue CPR

questions.text: Which of the following statements about massive transfusion management are correct? A) PRBC should be administered first to address hypoxia and acidosis. B) Blood components should be transfused in a 1:1:1 ratio of PRBC: FFP: PRP, beginning with PRBC. C) Blood products should be warmed during transfusion to prevent hypothermia-induced coagulopathy. D) Platelets should be administered first to prevent coagulopathy. E) Components are stored at different temperatures: PRBC at 4°C, FFP at -30°C (thawed before use), and platelets at room temperature (20-24°C).

options.label: A
options.text: A, B, and C only

options.label: B
options.text: A, B, C, and E only

options.label: C
options.text: B, C, and D only

options.label: D
options.text: B,C D, and E only

questions.correct_answer: B. A, B, C, and E only

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after being bitten by a snake on his left ankle. He presents with severe swelling of the left leg, gingival bleeding, and incoagulable blood on the 20-minute whole blood clotting time test. You decide to administer polyvalent antivenom serum (ASV). Twenty minutes after starting the ASV infusion, the patient develops urticaria, cough, and abdominal pain. His blood pressure drops to 85/50 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Discontinue ASV infusion permanently

options.label: B
options.text: Continue ASV infusion and administer corticosteroids

options.label: C
options.text: Stop ASV infusion temporarily and treat with epinephrine

options.label: D
options.text: Administer heparin to counteract coagulopathy

questions.correct_answer: C. Stop ASV infusion temporarily and treat with epinephrine
questions.explanation:
Complication

Timing

Symptoms

Management

Early (Anaphylactic) Reaction

10-180 minutes after starting ASV

- Itching, urticaria

- Nausea, vomiting

- Cough, abdominal colic

- Fever, tachycardia

- Hypotension

- Bronchospasm

- Angioedema

1. Stop ASV infusion immediately

2. Administer epinephrine (adrenaline) IM or SC

3. Give antihistamines and corticosteroids

4. Treat shock if present

5. Resume ASV at a slower rate after symptoms subside

Pyrogenic Reaction

1-2 hours after treatment

- Fever

- Rigors

- Hypotension

- Symptomatic treatment

- Antipyretics

- IV fluids if needed

Late (Serum Sickness) Reaction

5-24 days (mean 7 days) after ASV

- Fever

- Itching

- Urticaria

- Arthralgia

- Lymphadenopathy

- Proteinuria

- Antihistamines

- Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone) for 5-7 days

questions.text: A 28-year-old farmer is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being bitten by a snake on his right leg. He presents with severe pain and swelling at the bite site, and examination reveals two puncture wounds. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and he has gingival bleeding. The 20-minute whole blood clotting time test shows that the blood is incoagulable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer 50 ml of polyvalent antivenom

options.label: B
options.text: Administer 150-200 ml of polyvalent antivenom

options.label: C
options.text: Apply a tight tourniquet above the bite site

options.label: D
options.text: Administer heparin to manage coagulopathy

questions.correct_answer: B. Administer 150-200 ml of polyvalent antivenom
questions.explanation:
Management

Details

Indications/Notes

First Aid

-Do not allow the victim to walk (Carry)

-Avoid tourniquets, except in specific cases(No)

- Reassure patient

- Immobilize bitten limb

- Transport to the hospital quickly

- Tell the doctor about any systemic symptoms

Tourniquets only for severe elapid/sea snake bites with >0.5h but <2-3h transport time

Evaluation

- Check for signs of envenomation

- Monitor vital signs

- Perform 20-minute whole blood clotting time

- Check coagulation profile, CPK, renal function

Incoagulable blood indicates systemic envenomation by Viperidae

Antivenom Therapy

- Mild: 50 ml

- Moderate: 50-100 ml

- Severe: 150-200 ml

Effective against the 4 most important venomous snakes in India, namely, Cobra, Common Krait, Russell's viper and saw-scaled viper.

Indications:

- Haemostatic abnormalities

- Neurotoxicity

- Cardiovascular dysfunction

- Impaired consciousness

- Rhabdomyolysis

- Extensive local swelling

Antivenom Administration

- Dilute in 5 ml/kg body weight of isotonic saline/5% Dextrose

- Infuse over 1-2 hours

- Monitor for hypersensitivity reactions

Repeat if severe signs persist after 1-2 hours or if coagulability is not restored within 6 hours

Supportive Care

- Tetanus prophylaxis

- Antibiotics (if severe local reaction)

- Manage respiratory paralysis

- Fresh frozen plasma/cryoprecipitates for severe bleeding

Avoid heparin, corticosteroids, and EDTA.

questions.text: A 32-year-old farmer is brought to the emergency department after being bitten by a snake while working in his field in rural India. He presents with severe local pain, swelling, and gum bleeding. Within 2 hours, he develops diplopia, dysphagia, and progressive weakness in his limbs. Laboratory tests show prolonged prothrombin time and decreased fibrinogen levels. Which of the following snakes is most likely responsible for this envenomation?

options.label: A
options.text: Cobra

options.label: B
options.text: Russell's viper

options.label: C
options.text: Saw-scaled viper

options.label: D
options.text: Krait

questions.explanation:
Feature

Cobra

(Option A)

Krait

(Option D)

Russell's Viper

Saw-scaled Viper

(Option C)
Image

Venom Type

Neurotoxic

Neurotoxic

Hemotoxic and Neurotoxic

Hemotoxic

Local Symptoms

Mild to moderate pain and swelling

Minimal local symptoms

Severe pain, swelling, and tender lymphadenopathy

Severe pain and swelling

Neurological Symptoms

- Ptosis

- Paralysis of jaw/tongue

- Pooling of secretions

- Paradoxical respiration

- Ptosis

- Paralysis of jaw/tongue

- Pooling of secretions

- Paradoxical respiration

- Diplopia

- Dysphagia

- Dysarthria/ dysphonia

- Descending paralysis

Generally not present

Bleeding Manifestations

Rare

Rare

- Gum bleeding

- Epistaxis

- Hematuria

- Retro-peritoneal bleeding

- Gum bleeding

- Epistaxis

- Hematuria

- Can persist for weeks

Renal Complications

Rare

Rare

- Acute tubular necrosis

- Renal failure

Possible, but less common

Coagulation Profile

Usually normal

Usually normal

- Prolonged PT/INR

- Decreased fibrinogen

- Thrombocytopenia

- Prolonged PT/INR

- Decreased fibrinogen

- Thrombocytopenia

20 WBCT Test

Normal (solid clot)

Normal (solid clot)

Abnormal (rapid clot degradation)

Abnormal (rapid clot degradation)

Onset of Symptoms

Rapid onset of neurological symptoms

Often delayed onset, may occur during sleep

Rapid onset of local and systemic symptoms

Rapid onset of local symptoms

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU with sepsis secondary to a urinary tract infection. After 48 hours, she develops acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. Her chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates, and her PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 180 mmHg on PEEP of 8 cm H2O. An echocardiogram shows normal cardiac function. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiate high-frequency oscillatory ventilation

options.label: B
options.text: Start inhaled nitric oxide therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Begin low tidal volume ventilation with 6 mL/kg predicted body weight

options.label: D
options.text: Administer high-dose corticosteroids

questions.correct_answer: C. Begin low tidal volume ventilation with 6 mL/kg predicted body weight
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis (Berlin Definition)

Timing

Within 1 week of known clinical insult or new/worsening respiratory symptoms

Chest Imaging

Bilateral opacities not fully explained by effusions, collapse, or nodules

Origin of Edema

Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload

Oxygenation
  • Mild (Grade A): 200 mmHg < PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 mmHg (with PEEP or CPAP ≥ 5 cm H2O)
  • Moderate (Grade B): 100 mmHg < PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 200 mmHg
  • Severe (Grade C & D): PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 100 mmHg

Management Recommendations

Grade A (Mild)
  • Low tidal volume ventilation (4–8 ml/kg predicted body weight) and lower inspiratory pressures (plateau pressure < 30 cm H2O)

Grade B (Moderate)
  • Minimized plateau and driving pressures
  • High PEEP (35–50 cmH2O for 20–40 s)
  • Prone positioning
  • Recruitment maneuvers
  • ECMO in selected patients

Grade C (Severe)
  • Neuromuscular blockade in early ARDS
  • Conservative fluid management
  • Inhaled vasodilators as rescue therapy
  • Avoid routine use of pulmonary artery catheter

Grade D (Severe)
  • Avoid high-frequency oscillatory ventilation
  • Avoid β2-agonists for improving outcomes

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the ICU with severe pneumonia. He develops worsening respiratory symptoms and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray within 5 days. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiological mechanism occurring in the alveoli during the early phase of this patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased surfactant production

options.label: B
options.text: Thickening of the alveolar basement membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Accumulation of protein-rich edema fluid

options.label: D
options.text: Fibrosis of the alveolar walls

questions.correct_answer: C. Accumulation of protein-rich edema fluid
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Direct Lung Injury Causes
  • Pneumonia
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • Pulmonary contusion
  • Near-drowning
  • Toxic inhalation injury

Indirect Lung Injury Causes
  • Sepsis
  • Severe trauma
  • Multiple bone fractures
  • Pancreatitis
  • Burns
  • Multiple transfusions
  • Drug overdose
  • Cardiopulmonary bypass
Pathophysiology
  • Exudative Phase (0-7 days):

- Injury to alveolar capillary endothelial cells and type I pneumocytes

- Increased capillary permeability

- Accumulation of protein-rich edema fluid in alveoli and interstitium

- Formation of hyaline membranes

- Neutrophil infiltration and activation

- Release of pro-inflammatory cytokines (e.g., TNF-α, IL-1, IL-8)

- Impaired gas exchange and reduced lung compliance

  • Proliferative Phase (7-21 days):

- Proliferation of type II pneumocytes

- Resolution of alveolar edema

- Early fibroproliferation

  • Fibrotic Phase (>21 days):

- Collagen deposition and fibrosis in some patients

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents to the emergency department with fever, tachypnea, and altered mental status. Laboratory results show: WBC: 14,000/μL Serum lactate: 1.8 mmol/L Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL (baseline 0.9 mg/dL) Chest X-ray reveals a right lower lobe infiltrate. The patient requires 5 L/min of oxygen to maintain SpO2 > 90%. According to the Sepsis-3 criteria, which of the following is the most accurate diagnosis for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS)

options.label: B
options.text: Sepsis

options.label: C
options.text: Severe sepsis

options.label: D
options.text: Septic shock

questions.text: A 35-year-old male trauma patient is undergoing a massive transfusion protocol (MTP) following a severe motor vehicle accident. Two hours into the MTP, he developed acute respiratory distress. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral infiltrates. His blood pressure is within normal limits, and BNP (Brain Natriuretic Peptide) levels are not elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)

options.label: B
options.text: Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)

options.label: C
options.text: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

options.label: D
options.text: Cardiogenic pulmonary edema

questions.explanation:
Feature

TRALI (Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury)

TACO (Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload) (Option A)

Definition

Acute non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema following blood transfusion.

Acute pulmonary edema due to volume overload from blood transfusion.

Onset

Usually within 6 hours of transfusion.

Can occur during or up to 12 hours post-transfusion.

Pathophysiology

Immune-mediated injury to pulmonary capillaries leads to fluid leakage into alveoli.

Volume overload causes increased hydrostatic pressure in the pulmonary circulation.

Symptoms

Sudden onset of dyspnea, hypoxemia, fever, hypotension.

Dyspnea, orthopnea, rapid weight gain, hypertension.

Physical Findings

Crackles, tachypnea, no signs of fluid overload (e.g., jugular venous distension).

Crackles, tachypnea, signs of fluid overload (e.g., elevated JVP, peripheral edema).
Chest X-ray Findings

 

Bilateral diffuse pulmonary infiltrates (non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema).

 Cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema, pleural effusions (cardiogenic pulmonary edema).

Blood Pressure

Hypotensive or normal.

Hypertensive.

Laboratory Findings

Neutrophilia, leukocytosis, and anti-HLA antibodies in donor blood (in some cases).

Elevated BNP (brain natriuretic peptide), no specific markers for TACO.

Treatment

Supportive care (oxygen, mechanical ventilation if necessary), no diuretics.

Diuretics (e.g., furosemide), oxygen, stopping or slowing the transfusion.

Prevention

Use of leukocyte-reduced or HLA-matched blood products.

Slow transfusion rate, avoid excess volume, and monitor for fluid overload.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with severe postpartum hemorrhage. Her vitals are: BP- 70/40 mmHg, HR- 135/min, RR- 28/min, Blood loss- Approximately 2L, ABC score- 3 Massive Transfusion Protocol is initiated. After round 1 of transfusion (4 units PRBC + 2 units FFP), the patient continues to bleed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer Factor VIIa immediately

options.label: B
options.text: Give 4 units PRBC, 4 units FFP, and 1 unit SDP in Round 2

options.label: C
options.text: Only give additional PRBC to correct anemia

options.label: D
options.text: Start cryoprecipitate without checking fibrinogen levels

questions.correct_answer: B. Give 4 units PRBC, 4 units FFP, and 1 unit SDP in Round 2
